newsitem.title: USA: Chile still sees U.S. support for free trade, NAFTA.
newsitem.headline: Chile still sees U.S. support for free trade, NAFTA.

text.p: Chilean Finance Minister Eduardo Aninat said Monday he still sees political support in the United States for free trade and treaties like the NAFTA.

"Personally, I have the impression and the conviction that both the Republican and the Democratic parties believe in free trade and in scrapping restrictions," said Aninat, who hopes Chile will eventually join the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA).

"We've also seen how the United States acted at the World Trade Organization and in the Uruguay Round of GATT," added Aninat, who is chairing the IMF-World Bank annual meeting. "What's important is to avoid a return to protectionism."
The NAFTA's original partners, Canada, Mexico and the United States, invited Chile in December, 1994 to open talks on its entry.
Those talks, however, stalled last year because the United States did not approve a key "fast-track" authority to ensure a smooth negotiation process.

Although free trade is championed by most U.S. political leaders, popular support faded after the 1995 Mexican peso crisis. The Republican-controlled Congress and President Bill Clinton, a Democrat who expects to win a second term in November, did not produce a "fast-track" bill in this election year, and officials have made no promises for 1997.
Aninat said Chile was cautiously waiting for the dust to settle after the U.S. elections.
"We are ready to do whatever is necessary to have an adequate negotiation, but what has happend was beyond our control," he said. "You need two partners for this dance, and only one was ready".
